bibl.title: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to James Carroll, February 20, 1907

div1.p: Mabel Lazear sympathizes with Carroll over his lack of pension, noting how difficult it was for her to receive support. She comments on Mansfelde's effort regarding credit due Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to James Carroll, February 20, 1907
div1.p:
Thank you
so much for your kind
note and the pamphlets-
It is an out rage that the
Government has done nothing
for you- I suppose you
knew it - but I must
suggest that if a Bill
is in the Senate for you
you must have some one
with Political influence
to look after it-

You can't imagine how
very hard I worked for
the mere pitance I received
from the Government
and so many influencial
people did every thing that
they could- Writing to
Senators and Congress men
but I do not think it would
have gone through but
for a very influencial
friend with a bill who
went to Washington and
work hard-

Dr Mansfelde writes he
is going to have the pension
increased - that -- the children
at least have never received
anything from the Government
is an outrage-

Dr Mansfelde I feel is kind-
ness itself - but what he is
trying to prove is still rather
a mystery- If there are men
who feel Major Reed deserves
all the credit I don't think
he can change them-
Why is he not willing to
simply work for the pensions

My kindest regards to
you and Mrs Carroll
